I think the two hypothesis to explain why we store Pokèmon were we store them might be a false dichotomy, just putting up two hypothesis and deciding it must be one of them, does not mean it is one of them. There could be plenty of other reasons than just form and focal point to how we remeber things, it could also be multifactorial.
I think the reason we store Pokèmon close to faces, could rather be that for once Pokémon are somewhat close to peole in most peoples mind (they have a personality, they are attached to us, they depend on us and the other way around etc). It is also important (given you want to play the game successfully) to be able to quickly differentiate between two Pokèmon, even if they look rather similar to each other. Much like it is important for our survival, especially when we are children, to be able to quickly differentiate between two similar but different faces for example family members.

It's amazing how the more we find out about amyloid plaques and Alzheimer's, the more it sounds like classical blood clotting and thrombosis cascades, where the autocatalyzing prion forms of amyloid and tau are like the intermediate clotting factors in the blood during the cascade. Beta-Amyloid is highly abundant in blood, made by leukocytes, and the plaques in the brain seem to start centered or associated with blood vessels (so, clotting of leakage through the BBB?). And amyloid/tau play a role in blood clotting https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28677497


Alzheimer's is like the brain's version of disseminated intravascular coagulation. Maybe we should start approaching Alzheimer's the same way we do clotting diseases and other amyloid based clotting problems: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10702818
Interesting research

Came for the pokemon, stayed for the Alzheimer's. I'm thinking back to some headlines that mentioned diabetes meds (or something else) seemed to reduce symptoms of Alzheimer's. Makes me wonder if the meds - or other conditions at that -  might be alter epigenetic expression or even modulating enzyme activity associated with these prions and/or plaques. Metabolic and genomic functions are tricky beasts and I think there could be further correlation. But I'm not versed enough to dig into that so I'll just throw this thought out there ;)

I am partially visually impaired from birth, and as a result, objects have always looked blurry to me. Because of this, my brain really does tend to fill in the blanks and complete images of characters or places that I can't really see clearly on TV or even for people in real life. This also happens  when I'm listening to audiobooks, where there are no pictures or because I don't look at the screen half the time  when I'm watching shows due to my limited vision and prefer to rely more on my listening skills to determine what is going on.  Then, when I actually get a chance to have a really close up look at the characters or objects, such as a photo that can be held right up to my eyes,  when I get  to hold a figure of my favourite characters, or even when I finally decide to have a close look at the screen,  I do get a little bit confused at first trying to recognise them because I had to unlearn what my brain already established they looked like. This happens even today. Even so, I'm pretty sure some of what I know is still something my brain made up as I can't see with 100% accuracy xD

The infectious particle model isn't new for Alzheimer's disease by a long shot, not sure why it's making the news now. Calling Tau and A-beta seed/infectious particles prions instead seems like an attention grab to me though. Prion is the name of a specific protein, PrP, so it's not appropriate to just start calling other things that too just because they exhibit similar behavior.

It's conceptually equivalent to saying a cat is actually a dog because it knows how to fetch.

It's also a bizarre way to WANT to rebrand Alzheimer's disease, considering that actual prion disease is completely untreatable and incurable.

Regarding prions, I have a really good idea where they come from. Prions are in nerve tissue, and I would guess that a rare steak is teeming with prions. But aren't they testing for that, you ask? Up until recently, prions were unknown. But beef has been butchered for consumption after they were fed a now-banned feed containing the meat of cattle that were already infected, but not yet old enough to show symptoms. Worse, it used to be common practice to grind up the carcasses of any cattle that died at the stockyard to feed the incoming cattle.
I would love to see the study and see if anyone has studied vegetarians since childhood versus people who are meat eaters since childhood. Do the vegetarians' brains contain prions? I have so many questions!

I've been far-sighted since birth. My parents noticed and figured it out when I was around 4, getting me glasses to correct. I also have a certain level of face-blindness. It's less that I can't recognize someone, but asked to describe someone's face in my mind's eye (like to a police sketch artist), I couldn't even describe my close friends and family. I actually rely heavily on someone's hair color, texture, and style to identify them. Having poor near vision when I was an infant and experienced faces very intimately and now having difficulty "filing" faces mentally seems to make a lot of sense with this research.

Ok....ok the Alzheimer's prions idea is really interesting and technically yea you could dub them as such based of protein clumping protein. Tau and more so amyloid do clump. Amyloid clumps because it becomes insoluble at a certain length and depending how your cell cleaves the full amyloid protein dictates whether it clumps or not. Over time these single long chain and insoluble amyloid proteins aggregate pulling more insoluble proteins forming these clusters and as they are in the brain they remove functionally and generally memory/retention. Is that initial insoluble amyloid particle a prion...... I dont know, definitions for prions are a little bit in the air for me. Did my thesis on a lot of this, such a fascinating area of research
